page.title: 03**** WILDLIFE(Flora) ****
page.content: The uprooting of hedges to increase (and facilitate care of) fields,the ploughing,draining and fertilising of soil which are part of arable farming destroy habitats.But pastoral farming allows some to remain.Eg at Llynclys Pool,{undrained wetlands}permit growth of water forget_me_nots,golden flags, ragged robin,rushes,watermint,louse_ wort and duckweed. On higher{naturally_drained pasture are ox_eye daisies,shepherd's purse, chickweed and,on cow pastures,bugle. The edges of arable land support wild poppies,nettles,brambles,wild dog and briar roses. The few trees in the area tend to be the commoner species of oak,ash,hazel and sycamore;the hedges are hazel and hawthorn and support semi_wild pink rugosa roses.
